pages.text: Charnia Masoni comes from the late Ediacaran, with fossils found from the Charnwood Forest, UK; Flinders Ranges, South Australia and White Sea, Russia. It is a leaf-like petalonamid lifeform, and can be found in from deep to shallow waters, growing up to 66 cm in height, and possibly partook in filter feeding from the surrounding water.

Charnia claims the title of being the first universally accepted indisputable lifeform from Precambrian strata, as well as being the most recongisable to the general public. The generic names derives from the place 'Charnwood Forest', where it was found. The specific name derives from the surname of Roger Mason, a school boy who found the first fossil.
